sg.yeefan.searchenginewrapper
Class SearchEngineWrapper

java.lang.Object
  sg.yeefan.searchenginewrapper.SearchEngineWrapper

public class SearchEngineWrapper
extends java.lang.Object

A wrapper for a search engine. This wrapper reads from an input file containing the query strings, and writes to an output file containing the search engine results.

The following gives a sample usage of this class: 


 SearchEngineWrapper wrapper = new SearchEngineWrapper();
 wrapper.setKeys(keys);
 wrapper.setInputFile(inputFile);
 wrapper.setOutputFile(outputFile);
 wrapper.setClient(client);
 wrapper.setNumResults(numResults);
 wrapper.run();
The input file consists of lines of the form label: query, as illustrated in the following example: 

 0001: "tan yee fan"
 0002: sensei's library
 0003: java tutorial
The output file is in XML format. The root element is <resultslist>, which contains a <results> element for each query in the input file. An example of the output XML file is shown below: 

 <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
 
 <resultslist>
 
 <results>
 <label>0001</label>
 <query>"tan yee fan"</query>
 <totalresults>468</totalresults>
 <startindex>1</startindex>
 <starttime>1269907585796</starttime>
 <endtime>1269907587203</endtime>
 <elapsedtime>1407</elapsedtime>
 <fatalerror>0</fatalerror>
 <result>
 <url>http://www.comp.nus.edu.sg/~tanyeefa/</url>
 <title>TAN Yee Fan</title>
 <snippet>Webpage of Tan Yee Fan.</snippet>
 </result>
 ... more <result> elements ...
 </results>
 
 ... more <results> elements ...
 
 </resultslist>
Most fields in the <results> element should be self explanatory. The times are given in milliseconds; and <starttime> and <endtime> refer to the number of milliseconds past the midnight of 1970 January 1 (UTC) as returned by System.currentTimeMillis().

As search engines place restrictions on the number of results they return per request, the search engine wrapper automatically issues as many requests as needed to obtain the required number of results for a particular query string. An exponential backoff delay mechanism is implemented for temporary search engine failures before reissuing the query. The first failure causes a waiting time of waitIntervalFirst seconds, and every subsequent failure will cause the waiting time to be multiplied by waitIntervalMultiplier, with the maximum waiting time capped at waitIntervalMax seconds. If the search engine requires a registration key, this wrapper can manage a pool of keys to be rotated. In this case, the key will be switched to the next key if the number of consecutive waits for a key reaches maxNumWaits, or immediately if the search engine returns a quota exceeded error. The parameters waitIntervalFirst, waitIntervalMultiplier, waitIntervalMax, and maxNumWaits can be set in this class.

Author:
Tan Yee Fan
See Also:
SearchEngineClient, SearchEngineResults
